The entirety of the play takes place in this restaurant, with the restaurant itself as a symbol of the play’s larger theme. Various regulars enter each scene: Wolf (a bookie), Risa (a waitress), West (the owner of a funeral parlor), Hambone (a man with some mental/emotional disability causing him to only say the same things over and over), and Sterling (an ex-con who is trying to restart his life). Wilson uses each of these characters to express different struggles of African-American life in the turbulent 1960s. Memphis, for example, has been notified that his diner will be torn down as part of the city’s rebuilding project, and his anger at what he feels is too-low a sale price reflects the anger of the black community continually being undermined while the larger society and culture rebuild and evolve. Sterling’s search for a new life and his to-some-questionable ethics represents a generation of African-Americans willing to do what is needed to be done in order to forge new lives amidst change. For me, the best fantasy fictI am fond of fantasy fiction aimed at young adults – I mean, young adults need some jumping off point to get to Tolkien. For me, the best fantasy fiction does three things well: (1) build out a universe and mythology that seems to live and breathe; (2) tell an sweeping epic that feels as if it is centuries old; and most importantly (3) present me a band of characters that I like and am rooting for. This book – the first in Peterson’s Wingfeather Saga tetralogy – hits on 2 of 3 fairly well, but it misses on the most important one. Janner Igiby lives in a quaint village with his grandfather, mother, younger brother Tink, and younger sister Leeli. They live in the land of Skree, a land which has been oppressed by the lizard-like army (called Fangs) of the villain Gnag the Nameless. Janner and his siblings get on the bad side of a few Fangs one day, setting off a series of events that end up with the Igiby family having to flee their quaint village. As they flee, Janner and his siblings begin to find out more about their father (who had passed away nine years previously), their grandfather (who kept the details of his younger days to himself), and the history and events of Skree. To my earlier point about what good fantasy fiction needs to do, this book does build out a unique universe that feels both medieval and believable. The fangs work as characters, the land has dragons and a Dragon Day Festival, and footnotes in each chapter reference imaginary books and poems making the history feel real. My biggest critique is the way Peterson advances the plot. The plot is fairly linear, with one event leading to the next. But most of the events that occur do so because of the rash actions of the Igiby children. Tink is impetuous, and Leeli wanders off twice; and their actions lead to dire situations for the entire family and their village. Moreover, the main characters only survive these dire situations by several deus ex machinas. This is lazy plotting, and after awhile, the manufactured tension irritated me; in turn, my irritation led me to wishing ill on the Igiby children – not what I ought be feeling towards the protagonists of a tetralogy. review: August Wilson’s brilliant 10-play Century Cycle captures the black experience in America in the 20th century. Each play is set in a different decade, August Wilson’s brilliant 10-play Century Cycle captures the black experience in America in the 20th century. Each play is set in a different decade, and muses on different themes of the black experience. Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom is chronologically the third play in the cycle. The play takes place in 1927 in Chicago – the only one of the Century Cycle that doesn’t take place in Pittsburgh. A band is rehearsing in a studio and preparing to record an album together. Most of the band are men in their mid-50’s, but they are joined by a thirty-something, brash trumpeter named Levee who brings a swagger and confidence that rubs the band the wrong way. Ma Rainey is the lead vocals and also the unquestioned leader of the band; it is her album they are recording. The play explores several dynamics as these characters attempt to record the album: the dynamic between Ma and Levee, the dynamic between Ma and her white manager and white record label exec, the dynamic between the younger Levee and the older bandmates. As in the earlier plays in the cycle, Wilson uses the different characters and their perspectives to subtly and overtly explore important questions across multiple angles. In Ma Rainey, Wilson explores the changing power dynamics for blacks during the 1920s. For example, in one scene, Toledo calls for the bandmates to recognize that blacks at this time were considered “leftovers”; and that whites held all the control. Ma Rainey’s ability to dictate the details of the rehearsal on her terms, however, represents how blacks who had power ought to use that power. Levee reflected a position where he was willing to play the power dynamic game in subordination to whites only insofar as it allowed him to build his own power so as to change the dynamic later on. Wilson’s framing of these viewpoints was really well done. Throughout, Wilson’s dialogue and prose sparkle with energy and emotion. More than in Gem of the Ocean or Joe Turner’s Come and Gone, the dialogue in Ma Rainey had more overt anger and stridency of tone. Characters essentially argue through the majority of the scenes. This choice of prose was made due to the primary theme of power struggles, and it serves that theme well. My one critique of this play is its lack of subtlety. In both Gem and Joe Turner, the themes are explored symbolically or beneath the surface of the dialogue. In Ma Rainey, the theme is explored expositorily as characters verbalized their viewpoints. I generally prefer my plays to be more understated. Nevertheless, it’s still a terrific play; Wilson is 3-for-3 in his 10-play masterpiece. ...more

Charlie is a mentally disabled man who undergoes an I read the short story version of this decades ago, but this was my first read of the full novel. Charlie is a mentally disabled man who undergoes an experimental surgery to increase his intelligence. The surgery is a success, and over a period of about 6-7 months, his IQ increases dramatically. As his IQ changes, however, Charlie’s perspective on his relationships with the people in his life also changes. For example, he finally understands that his co-workers at the bakery he worked at weren’t his friends; they had been making fun of him. Charlie also begins to recall memories of his childhood and the abuse he experienced from his mom who struggled with supporting and raising a disabled child. The prose is told in a series of first-person journal entries describing Charlie’s feelings and the events of his days. This is an effective narrative, as we can see Charlie’s mental development through the development of the prose in these entries. The reader also becomes quickly attached to Charlie through these personal glimpses of his struggles. I had two critiques of the story. First, the pacing felt uneven to me. There were stretches in the middle that felt like we were capturing too much minutiae, and the plot wasn’t advancing quickly enough. And then towards the end, there was a breakneck rush towards the finish line. I wished the pacing had been more consistent. I don’t even know that you can call it a memoir, Slate is a comedian and an actress, and in this book, she puts her creativity to use in memoir form. I don’t even know that you can call it a memoir, though, since memoirs actually share details about events. These chapters read more like impressions of scenes, rather than actual scenes. It’s like describing the colors you see without actually describing what you see. Maybe a diary rather than a memoir? Whatever you call it, it didn’t work for me. The book is filled with short chapters that read like stream of consciousness (often bad) poetry describing various stages of her life. For memoirs or diaries to work for me, though, they must: (a) provide moments that resonate emotionally; and (b) provide insights on the human condition. This book fails on both accounts. A lot of that has to do with Slate’s prose. It’s one thing to have creative prose; it’s another thing to have so much of it, or to use it in such a way that it overwhelms any underlying emotion or point. That is very much the case for this book. The prose is this “Oh look how quirky I am”, different-to-be-different writing style that I would call a poor man’s Etgar Keret. It’s how a high school sophomore writes in a creative writing class after reading David Sedaris. Look at this sentence: “When I imagine my ingredients, I imagine that my muscles are made of plums, that my heart is a giant ruby with a light bulb in it, that my blood is goldenrod yellow, and the bones inside my body are made from lions’ bones and shells, and that my brain is made of steak and silk and Hawaiian Punch.” Or this sentence: “What if a moonbeam gets caught in my soup and I swallow it in a sip and then I always float a little bit off the ground because there is a moonbeam in my stomach?” These sentences try too hard to be quirky or profound and are neither. Part of the problem is that Slate really only tries to convey two points and doesn’t land either. The first point she communicates is that she is quirky and different and independent. But it comes off as disingenuous. Ever meet a girl at a party who has had like three sips of beer and goes around loudly proclaiming “Oh my gosh, I am so wasted right now! And I get so wild and crazy when I’m drunk. I can’t even.” Except they’re not drunk, wild, or crazy? In my experience, the more someone states they are quirky, different, and independent, the less likely they are really those things. And the second point she tries to communicate is that she has had relationship issues. But she doesn’t really provide any relationship particulars; rather, she describes vague heartbreaks and relationship problems in one chapter, but then follows that chapter up with a chapter where she declares things like she is an actual, literal mouse. This makes everything, including her real heartaches, feel like fantasy rather than reality. This is what I mean when I noted that her prose overwhelms her point. In this nearly one-person monologue, a dying man named Guy (or possibly his name isn’t Guy, and he is just referred to as a guy; some Everyman) sits in a wheelchair and shares his final thoughts. Throughout the play, he reads and shuffles through a series of index cards, as if he has tried to record and plan out his last words. And yet, Guy’s thoughts are often confused; his thoughts fading off; his cards making no sense. Instead of profound maxims, Guy tries to get the audience to focus on an image in their heads, or to listen to something played by the sound booth. I own more Superman T-shirts than MCU T-shirts combined. And I am currently wearing Superman pajama pants. All that to say, I am not remotely objective when it comes to Superman; he is my absolute favorite character across all my nerd fandoms (MCU, DC, Star Wars, LotR, et al). Despite my rampant Superman fandom, I am still able to objectively rank some Superman story arcs over others. But believe you me, Superman: For All Seasons is as good as comics get. This story arc plays out in four acts, each told from the narrative perspective of different people: Pa Kent, Lois Lane, Lex Luthor, and Lana Lang. Spring (Pa) presents a graduating Clark coming to grips with the knowledge that, given his powers, the only way he can maximize the number of people he can positively impact is by moving away from Smallville to Metropolis. And the sadness that accompanies that decision is framed through both Pa’s and Clark’s eyes. I may have shed a tear or hundred in this act. The second act (summer via Lois) introduces us to Clark’s and Superman’s relationship with Lois. But it contrasts Lois’ fascination and growing affection for Superman with the loneliness that Superman feels in the big city. Despite being the most famous man in Metropolis, he might be the loneliest. I may have shed a tear or hundred in this act. Autumn is told through Lex’s eyes, and shows us Superman’s growing power and influence in the city, as well as his growing rivalry with Lex. And yet despite the growing power, Superman must wrestle with weakness, and come to grips with the knowledge that despite his power, he cannot save everyone. I may have shed a tear or hundred in this act. Winter (Lana) provides us with the full character of Superman: the tension between power and weakness, personal desire and responsibility, family vs the world, fear and conviction. I for sure shed many tears in this act. As good as the brilliant writing is the jaw-dropping artwork. Every frame looks like hand-painted watercolor, in a style reminiscent of The Adventures of Tintin, or illustrations from the Saturday Evening Post – beautifully classic. And many of the frames are worth staring at for long periods of time to study all of the details packed into each frame (especially in the Smallville scenes). The colors are generally muted in perfect contrast to the bright blues and reds of Superman. Most impressive in the artwork is the immense emotion in every face, especially Superman (ranging from wistful to sad to loving to heroic). I have read and love many of the graphic novels considered the greatest comics of all time (e.g. The Dark Knight Returns, Watchmen, Uncanny X-Men, etc), and yet I would take Superman: For All Seasons over any of them. My favorite comic graphic novel of all time. It’s perfect. ...more

If he is truly a superhero for the world and not just America, what does that look like; and how do we feel if he has to act against American interests in service of world peace? Most of his books focusI’ve read almost everything by Alexie, and I’ve enjoyed all of his works. His prose is a unique blend of poignancy and poetry. Most of his books focus on similar themes – growing up in poverty, alcoholism, abuse, racism, and Native American culture – but each book approaches these themes in different ways with different voices and in different situations. In this book, the main character is a 15-year-old boy named Zits. Zits has spent much of his life bouncing around between foster homes. He runs away from his most recent home, but gets caught by the police. He meets another young kid in jail that over time convinces Zits that violence is the answer. Zits eventually makes his way to a bank and shoots a bunch of people before he himself is shot. But rather than die, Zit is transported back in time to several different instances of violence against Native Americans (e.g. Red River in 1874, Little Bighorn) where he inhabits the bodies of different people as they participate in these atrocities. He experiences and witnesses violence being done both against and by Native Americans. Essentially, the entire book is a thought experiment about the nature of violence; what justifications we make for it; the arbitrary ethics around it. Moreover, Alexie describes many violent acts in detail, as if to shock the reader with the grotesque brutality of violence and murder. Alexie has never been known for subtlety – and he’s not trying to be subtle; in Flight, he makes it clear that nothing justifies violence against other human beings, and that killing is always a human failing. And yet despite the heaviness of the topic, there are several moments of hope in the book that reflect Alexie’s belief that human beings can make distinct and good choices amidst chaos. Another terrific read from Alexie....more

But more than Doescher’s ability to craft technically-perfect Shakespearean prose, what makes his books so good is his ability to cleverly match pop culture character to Shakespearean character. Here, for example, Doescher makes the Ghost of Christmas present Falstaff, and the Ghost of Christmas Future the ghost of Hamlet’s dad – so good. In another example, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern make a cameo as the two men who ask Scrooge for money for their charity at the beginning of the story. review: Frankly, I blame myself for reading this book. You see, I’m an admitted book snob. That is, I can’t enjoy a book just for its story; its prose and conFrankly, I blame myself for reading this book. You see, I’m an admitted book snob. That is, I can’t enjoy a book just for its story; its prose and construction also have to be high-quality for me to enjoy a book. And there were several red flags staring me in my face when I purchased this book. There’s the fact that Martin has written twelve books, releasing one almost every year. Generally writers that prolific are prolific because they are churning out garbage. And then there’s the “USA Today Bestseller” sticker on the front cover. Sorry, masses, but your judgment about books is terrible (hence the reason Twilight and 50 Shades were bestsellers). So it’s not a surprise that this book is one of the worst books I have ever read. Cooper O’Connor is a musician from Colorado who grew up in the loving care of his father, an open-air preacher. Cooper rebels against his loving father and strikes out on his own to make it as a musician in Nashville. He ends up meeting and falling in love with a musician named Daley before the book’s villain drives them apart. The story picks up years later when Cooper meets up with Daley again, with flashbacks filling in their history. Where do I begin in describing how poorly-written this was? We’ll start with the plot: it’s completely predictable. There was not a single event that occurred in this book that was remotely surprising. There’s a big reveal at the end about a man who rescued Cooper from a fire that could not have been more obvious. This plot was like one of those Hallmark-sponsored movies that appear on LifeTime. Secondly, the characterization of every character is pedestrian, without any nuance whatsoever. Every protagonist is perfect and good-looking and virtuous. Cooper is handsome and is apparently one of the greatest musicians who ever lived. He even volunteers in an old folks home, for crying out loud. Also, he’s secretly rich and loves giving away money. Meanwhile, his love interest is stunningly beautiful, and winsome, with a voice that is apparently one of the greatest voices of all time, and gosh-darn it, she never stopped loving Coop. Cooper’s dad is obviously the father figure everyone wants: forgiving, loving, etc. [Yes, I get that Martin was modeling this story after the Parable of the Prodigal Son, so of course the father is perfect. But that doesn’t explain the other idealized characters.] Meanwhile, the villain is of course slick and deceitful and malicious. He does everything evil, stopping just short of clubbing a baby seal. Good books create characters with depth and nuance. Thirdly, this prose is atrocious. I will often read a book with incredible prose and will read sentences or paragraphs out loud to my wife so she can appreciate the brilliance with me. This is the first book in a long while where I read whole passages out loud because of how laughably bad the prose is. It’s filled with clichés. The dialogue doesn’t sound natural, especially where characters are trying to be profound. The prose was especially bad in scenes where Daley and Cooper were singing together. Martin would list a dozen song titles, as if showing off his knowledge of cool songs that everybody loves. He did this in another scene that was describing a hymn sing. In these scenes, the detailed set list is unnecessary; it’s as if Martin is trying to appeal to his audience so that they read along and say, “I love that song/hymn, too!” Later, a character is stated to have died from a broken heart! Guys, this book! Lastly, the word “saccharine” was made for dreck like this. Good books wring out emotions from the reader organically, without contrived scenes. This book was one contrivance after another. For example, Cooper’s father wrote Cooper two letters. And Martin fully shares both letters to the reader expressing how much the father loved Cooper and was waiting with open arms for his return. These scenes of Cooper reading these emotional letters after his father’s death – come on, man; have you ever heard of subtlety, Charles? In another scene, Cooper is a server at a Nashville restaurant and he sees an old man come in every week and order two meals; but he only ever eats one and throws the other meal out. Cooper finds out that one meal was for the old man, and one was for his deceased wife. So Cooper cheers him up with a song. Ugh. These scenes are Hallmark cards come to life. I’d vent some more, but I need to clean my brain out with some good writing....more

Now imagine tapping into that conceit by adding a creative story on top of a sPeople like to feel smart; and this is especially true of smart people. Now imagine tapping into that conceit by adding a creative story on top of a smart concept and disguising it as good fiction — that’s this book. Now, this might sound like a criticism; it’s not meant to be. I admire the audacity of it all. I mean, the book combines the Fermi paradox with Kant’s conception of the thing-in-itself with an XFiles storyline. Aliens, metaphysics, and sci-fi — what’s not to like? Two men (Charles and Roy) are living together in an Antarctic science base deciphering radio signals in order to detect alien life. One of them (Roy) believes Kant’s conception of ding an sich solves the Fermi paradox. That leads to him almost killing Charles. The book then jumps forward in time. Charles leads a sad sack life, unable to move beyond his Antarctic trauma. I had to put down the book and weep with joy for five solid minutes at the climactic moment. The first few chapters provide the grounding – they explain why different translations exist, and why we need both exegesis (understanding a passage in its context) and hermeneutics (how to interpret a passage and apply it to today). The remaining chapters then tackle each of the different genres of Biblical writing (wisdom literature, prophetic books, epistles, gospels, etc), and explain how different each genre are from each other. On the other hand, the book’s reading level reads more like a book written for seminary students by two seminary professors. So this is not for everybody. Second, the authors explain how to balance exegesis against hermeneutics, but they seem to give so much weight to exegesis that they potentially limit (too much) the application of Biblical commands and principles to today. But frankly, I don’t really care about the opinion of any Cline fanboy who disagrees with my , so I’ll get to my point: this book is terrible. It’s not terrible because I don’t get nerd culture (I do), or didn’t catch all of the pop culture allusions (I did); it’s not terrible because I disliked Ready Player One (I thought it was fine) or am a Cline hater; it’s not terrible because I loved RP1 (I didn’t) and this fell short of lofty expectations (I had pretty low expectations) — it’s just not a very good book. Zack Lightman is a HS senior who was raised by a single mother (his father passed away in an accident when he was a baby). Zack is unsure what he wants to do with his life, but he is really, really good at a video game called Armada, a flight simulator where you run missions and take out alien ships to prevent an invasion. It turns out that the game has really been part of a decades-long military program to train and recruit people to pilot drones to fight an actual alien invasion. One morning, Zack and others around the globe are picked up by a global defense force (the Earth Defense Alliance) and informed that an alien horde of ships are en route to destroy mankind. Earth’s last hope are the skills of Zack and other gamers. Where do I begin unpacking how disappointing this book was? I’ll start with the plot: it’s so derivative as to be insulting. It’s one thing to be an homage to Ender’s Game and The Last Starfighter; it’s another to be a watered-down clone. Nothing in this plot is surprising, and everything is both telegraphed and expected. Second, in Ready Player One, the nerd culture allusions are the central plot device, so cramming that book with fan service at least made some sense. There is no point to any of the nerd allusions in Armada. The film dialogue quips the main characters swap are trite and unnecessary. Moreover, the nerd allusions are clumsily included and so forced, they come off as written by a poseur rather than a real fan. For example, two characters early on argue over whether Frodo’s Sting is a cooler weapon than Thor’s Mjolnir. Terrible. Third, everything that happens seems like it was written from the lens of either a nerd who wants to live out his deepest fantasies, or from the lens of a writer trying to appeal to what he thinks are nerds’ deepest fantasies. Examples: the anti-establishment, HS loner is the protagonist; the strong, badass, super hot gamer girl quickly falls in love with the protagonist not because of his looks but because of his pop culture wit, snarky wisecracks, and video game skills; society’s outcasts are really society’s greatest hope, etc. This book is either fanfic or pandering; either way, it irritated me. Lastly, the prose is atrocious. From the overly expository parts to the clunky dialogue to the clumsy plotting, this is just poorly written. Part of me wants to like this more than I do because I’m the intended audience — same feeling I had reading Ready Player One. Pro-capital punishment folks will either give this 1 star, or won’t give it a read at all, making the s self-selective. In this book, Stevenson brings to light the many systemic problems in the current legal system, particularly those that work against people of color and the poor. He provides real life examples of the cases he has worked on within his organization (Equal Justice Initiative) where dysfunctions (intentional or otherwise) within law enforcement, the judicial system, and communities resulted in death sentences for people (some innocent). He lays out chapters meant to horrify the reader about the plight of the mentally disabled, children, and poor mothers on death row. On top of these chapters, Stevenson tells the story of Walter McMillan, and the gross injustice that led to his death sentence. He was raised by a single father (a sociologist) whose idea of parenting was putting his son through social experiments to raise his consciousness to issues of race and racism. After his father is killed, BonBon joins with a man named Hominy Jenkins (the last remaining Little Rascal) in an attempt to reinstate both slavery and segregation. His actions lead him before the US Supreme Court – I’m telling you this plot is bonkers. Beatty is obviously not making the point that slavery and segregation were good things; rather he/BonBon is making the point that the ending of both slavery and segregation has not improved the lives of black people either. The Sellout is part satire and social commentary, tragedy and comedy, condemnation and education, with prose that is some mix of essay, poetry, rap, standup routine, and searing tirade. For the first fifty pages, I was reading section after section out loud to my wife so she could appreciate the brilliance of the writing. After Thrawn reveals himself to them, he is taken to meet Emperor Palpatine who takes a liking to Thrawn and places him into military training. The book then describes Thrawn’s quick ascendancy from lieutenant to commander to grand admiral as time after time he demonstrates a Sherlock-ian ability to understand situations, outthink everyone else, and intuit the best routes to victory. Many of these situations are part of a book-long cat-and-mouse/Sherlock-Moriarty game with a smuggler/rebel codenamed Nightswan. When a galactic senator takes over her parents’ mine on behalf of the Empire, Arihnda begins her push to power so that she can be the one controlling things. The remainder of the story is Jones and Chase following clues to ferret out the mysterious and dangerous Devereaux. The series takes place in a universe inhabited by four primary cultures tied to the four basic elements (fire, water, air, and earth). In this universe, certain people are gifted with the ability to “bend” their culture’s element; that is, they can manipulate the element in order to attack, defend, move, heal, etc. (e.g. earthbending might be used to cause the dirt at your feet to form a giant shield in front of you). Every few generations through reincarnation, one special individual (the avatar) is uniquely gifted with the ability to master all four elements in order to maintain peace and balance. The cartoon followed the life of one avatar named Aang as he grew into his role as avatar, and as he sought to bring the world back into balance after the fire nation attempted to conquer the other elemental tribes. This three-part graphic novel picks up several months/years after the series finale. Two of the series’ protagonists (Katara and her brother Sokka) return home to the southern water tribe village (the “South” of the title). They find that during their time away, their little village has been built up and is going through the process of modernization. The modernization efforts are being led by their sister tribe in the north, as well as the earth kingdom – all under the leadership of Katara’s and Sokka’s father. This graphic novel raises real questions about culture, politics, and the process of moving into the future while retaining and cherishing the past. Overall, I could easily imagine the animators making this a great episode. The main characters’ personalities showed through the illustrations, and the dialogue kept the show’s trademark earnestness and humor. For non-history buffs, the Battle of Dunkirk occurred over a 7-day period (May 26-June 4 1940). Germany essentially marched through Belgium and the Netherlands, trapping some 400,000 British and French troops in and around Dunkirk. Standing their ground and fighting would have resulted in massive casualties, possibly crippling the British ability to continue fighting and changing the course of the war. But evacuation seemed impossible given they were boxed in by German ground troops and the port situation in Dunkirk was essentially non-existent. The book details how a combination of luck (foggy weather helped ground the Luftwaffe for three days), poor German strategy (Hitler’s halt order on the German ground troops that delayed their attack by several days), and British resourcefulness (Britain commandeered every fishing boat, barge, naval boat, and seaworthy craft possible) resulted in the evacuation of nearly 340,000 troops across the English Channel. The display of courage and pluck became a rallying point for Britain’s war efforts. There are two types of non-fiction history books. One type focuses on a handful of key characters and traces the historical events through these characters, relating the events through fiction-esque prose. The other type takes a very documentary approach and throws in every detail, every historical reporting, every interview and quote available to cover the event. I very much enjoy the former type (Seabiscuit, Unbroken, and Boys in the Boat – my three favorite non-fiction books ever – are told in this vein). The latter type tends to be too dry or disjointed for my tastes. Unfortunately, this book falls under this latter category. Lord includes far too many characters and without any key central figures, the book lacks cohesion. Secondly, Lord’s told different facets of the evacuation across different chapters. But their timelines overlapped. The way Lord laid out these overlapping timelines often confused me. Lastly, the book included a handful of maps but really could have used a whole lot more. As Lord detailed the movement of different troops, I had to keep a map open on my phone in order to follow what was happening. Having more maps in every chapter would have helped the flow. Overall, I was disappointed – an event like Dunkirk should have been far more compelling and exciting than I found this book to be.
